User.name: Brandon Schwartz

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Sondeo realizado en la canal de san luis

Deep areas in humpy have good stability. All of our explosive work was only prying out freshly formed wind slabs and nothing stepped down. There is uncertainty as to what has slid in humpy (repeaters). The structure is poor with fist depth hoar at the ground. We did not find anything shallower than 180cm where we travelled, but we did not check every chute. Where the snowpack is shallow (repeaters) you could very likely pull out a large avalanche. Suspect...

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent activity on similar slopes; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This pit highlights the general problem in the Uintas right now. Weak snow near the ground is strengthening but it has a very strong, deep (2meter) slab on top. It's very unlikely that a single skier alone can trigger one of these monsters. The problem is that a smaller avalanche, or a large cornice can bring this hazard to life, and continues to do so even over a week since the last significant load. Prior to this pit we found a new HS-NC-R2,D3-O, 8'deep, 200' wide, 1000' vert. that occurred on a similar aspect in a steeper rocky slope. The high PST would suggest stability but the structure is still capable of producing big ones in many places. The deep snow cover is also capable of connecting in unusual ways and the weakness may still propagate long distances.
HS in vicinity of pit was generally around 200cm but ranged from 175cm to 225cm around the slope.
Objective: Practice skills and ID PWLs Site Characteristics: Small knoll, possible ski tracks, some logged trees, moderate sky view,

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug at crown of avalanche. Extremely deep snowpack, not typical of most areas people will be skiing. Extreme depth due to wind loading, sluffing, and previous avalanching from above. There was a significant amount of vegetation in the bottom of this pit. The open air space around the vegetation caused facets to form from 90cm to the ground. Graphically this looks shocking in the pit profile, but I would not expect to find this snowpack structure on similar slopes. The take home point is the slab, and the weak layer that failed and caused the avalanche.
Further loading from 2/23 NW wind?

The basal facet layer is stronger than I expected, and I found it non-reactive in this pit. Quite a bit of nicely hardening February snow. Depth of slab making it hard to test and likely difficult for a person to trigger an avalanche.
ECT column propagated after 30+ hits; removed 3/4 of the slab below the shovel, multiple extra hits from shoulder, then collapsed and propagated with boot to shovel. Very dense, hard slab above.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug during storm cycle expecting 18 inches tonight. Poor structure, Good Strength and no energy. This area is skied frequently by locals when snow is good. We skied 30 cm of fresh light snow to lower mountain. Level 1 class with good terrain management conditions.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: ; Collapsing, widespread; Recent activity on different slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Cooker day in Blue Canyon. Two Wet Slab avalanches hit Hwy 50 at the west end of canyon. Cliffs were dripping and lots of active Loose Wet activity during profile. Profile was done in a shady spot to see if suspect weak layer was wetted in the absence of direct radiation (Maybe from rain the evening prior). The suspect layer at 65cm was dry on this NE-facing slope. Avalanches nearby were all E (not NE like profile) and in the sun. Investigation at the bed surface and in the crown of highway-hit avalanches showed layer at 65cm was wetted.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent activity on similar slopes; We skied slope
Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Recent activity on different slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Recent 1-2’ soft slab avalanches triggered on wind loaded slopes. A large natural occurred on ridgleine above this pit 1/4 mile to the north between the time we left this pit (1415) and 1530. It was on a heavily wind loaded slope,broke from a cornice fall 4-8’ deep on facets near the ground. R3D3-N-O
Dug pit about 100ft up from our AA105 shot hole from control mission this am

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This is a fracture line profile performed on an slide that occurred right off State Highway 110A, on the east side of the road, across from Niagara Gulch.The approximate width was 50', track ran 80', and the length was 100'. The bed surface was a grassy slope, above a creek, with an unsupportive base.

Problematic layer 64-54 is gaining strength but not as fast as we would like... It's a deep snowpack and there is the concept of bridging however there is a weak point to every bridge. If you were to find the sweet spot the slope would produce a very large avalanche.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope; Snowmobile tracks on slope
Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Average crown height 60cm; Max 80cm, Min 30cm. Avalanche failed on a layer of 1mm FCsf immediately above a MFcr 89cm up from the ground. Avalanche propagated approximately 450 feet wide and ran approximately 350 vertical feet. Slope angle increased from 30 degrees at the crown to 36 degrees as the slope rolled over. Debris was measured up to 320cm deep.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Gusts to moderate. Moderate to high W to SW winds off the Dana Plateau. Visible snow transport down into the gullies on E. Peak of Dana, Coke- and Ripper Chutes. Did not see any evidence of natural avalanches during the weekend storm. Active wind loading ATL and NTL the whole time we were out until 1530. The snow BTL was mostly unaffected by the winds. Most evidence of instability was observed in the top 10 to 15 cm of the snowpack. Kick tests propagated and the soft wind slab broke into blocks.
